title: How to Fire a Financial Advisor Gracefully
subtitle: Learn the steps to end your relationship with a financial advisor without the stress and guilt.
content:
How to Fire a Financial Advisor Gracefully

I'm Tyler, a former financial advisor and portfolio manager. If any of this is helpful, check out this week's episode of the podcast, Your Money Guide on the Side, where we’ll go over this in even more depth and nuance.

1. Write a Simple Thank You Note

Start by writing to them and saying, “Thank you for your time. I've simply decided to move in a different direction with my financial planning.”

2. Keep It Simple

That’s it! Don’t let whatever guilt they put on you cost you another $5,000 to $10,000 bucks a year.

3. Remember, It’s Your Money

Always remember, it is your money. It’s not a bad prom date that you’re trying not to hurt.
